Description: Jar (albarello), stonepaste, painted in black with lotus medallions under a blue-strained glaze; 'Sultanabad' ware.
Curator's comments: Part of the distinctive Ilkhanid Sultanabad group of slip-painted ceramic wares, this albarello (medicine jar) is decorated with lotuses, each enclosed within a Buddhist-inspired, teardropshaped frame. A transparent blue glaze gives the jar a deeper colour in contrast with the grey-green slip-painted wares of this group. Sultanabad wares often display Chinese inspired motifs, but the appearance of similar lotuses on the Mamluk mosque lamp in this case shows that such motifs reached Egypt and Syria as well. This would have occurred either directly from China or through an Ilkhanid filter as a result of close contact between the Mamluks and the Ilkhanids both in war and peace.
